books.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III

chapters.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:1
verses.text: Homily III.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:2
verses.text: That evil comes of sloth, and virtue from diligence, and that neither wicked men, nor the devil himself, are able to do the wary man any harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:3
verses.text: The proof of this from many passages, and amongst others from those which relate to Adam and to Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:4
verses.text: The day before yesterday we set on foot our sermon concerning the Devil, out of our love for you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:5
verses.text: But others, the day before yesterday while these matters were being set on foot here, took their places in the theatre, and were looking on at the Devil's show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:6
verses.text: They were taking part in lascivious songs; ye were having a share in spiritual music.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:7
verses.text: They were eating of the Devil's garbage: ye were feeding on spiritual unguents.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:8
verses.text: Who pray decoyed them? Who pray separated them from the sacred flock? Did the Devil pray deceive them? How did he not deceive you? you and they are men alike; I mean as regards your nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:9
verses.text: You and they have the same soul, you have the same desires, so far as nature is concerned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:10
verses.text: How is it then that you and they were not in the same place? Because you and they have not the same purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:11
verses.text: On this account they indeed are under deception, but you beyond deception.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:12
verses.text: I do not say these things again as discharging the Devil from accusation, but as desiring earnestly to free you from sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:13
verses.text: The Devil is wicked; I grant this indeed, but he is wicked for himself not towards us if we are wary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:14
verses.text: For the nature of wickedness is of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:15
verses.text: It is destructive to those alone who hold to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:16
verses.text: Virtue is the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:17
verses.text: It is not only able to profit those who hold to it, but those nearest at hand too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:18
verses.text: And in order that thou mayest learn that evil is evil in itself, but good is also good to others, I provide thee with proverbial evidence: "My son" saith he "if thou art become evil, thou shall bear thine evils alone, but if wise, for thyself and thy neighbour".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:19
verses.text: They were deceived in the theatre, but ye were not deceived.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:20
verses.text: This is the greatest proof of things, a clear testimony, and unquestionable reasoning, that in every case, the purpose is master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:21
verses.text: Do thou accordingly use this method of proof, and if thou seest a man living in wickedness, and exhibiting all kinds of evil; then blaming the providence of God, and saying that by the necessity of fortune and fate and through tyranny of Demons He gave us our nature, and on all sides shifting the cause from himself indeed, and transferring it to the creator who provides for all; silence his speech not by word, but by deed, shewing him another fellow servant living in virtue and forbearance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:22
verses.text: There is no need of long speeches, no need of a complex plan, nor even of syllogisms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:23
verses.text: By means of deeds the proof is brought about.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:24
verses.text: He said to him: thou art a servant, and he is a servant; thou art a man and he is a man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:25
verses.text: Thou livest in the same world: thou art nourished with the same nourishment under the same heaven: How is it that thou art living in wickedness, he in virtue? on this account God allowed the wicked to be mingled with the good; and did not give one law to the wicked indeed, and appointed another world as a colony for the good, but mixed these and those; conferring great benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:26
verses.text: For the good appear more thoroughly approved when they are in the midst of those who try to hinder them from living rightly, and who entice them to evil, and yet keep hold of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:27
verses.text: "For there must" he saith "be also heresies among you that they which are approved may be made manifest among you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:28
verses.text: Therefore also on this account he has left the wicked to be in the world, in order that the good may shine the brighter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:29
verses.text: Dost thou see how great is the gain? But the gain is not owing to the wicked, but owing to the courage of the good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:30
verses.text: On this account also we admire Noe, not because he was righteous nor yet because he was perfect alone, but because in that perverse and wicked generation he preserved his virtue, when he had no pattern of virtue, when all men invited him to wickedness; and he went his whole way contrary to them, like some traveller, pursuing his way while the great multitude is being borne along vehemently.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:31
verses.text: On this account he did not simply say "Noe was just, perfect," but added "in his generation" in that perverse, that desperate generation, when there was no acquisition of virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:32
verses.text: To the good indeed then this was the gain from the wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:33
verses.text: Thus at all events, also trees tossed about by contrary winds, become stronger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:34
verses.text: And there is a gain to the wicked from their mixing with the good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:35
verses.text: They feel confusion, they are ashamed, they blush in their presence; and even if they do not abstain from evil, yet nevertheless they dare what they dare with secrecy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:36
verses.text: And this is no small thing not to have transgression publicly committed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:37
verses.text: For the life of the others becomes the accuser of the wickedness of these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:38
verses.text: Hear at least what they say about the righteous man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:39
verses.text: "He is grievous to us, even when beheld," and it is no small beginning of amendment to be tormented at his presence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:40
verses.text: For if the sight of the righteous man did not torment them, this word would not have been uttered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:41
verses.text: But to be stung, and pinched in conscience at his presence, would be no little hindrance to indulging in wickedness with pleasure, Dost thou see how great is the gain both to the good from the wicked, and to the wicked from the good? On this account God has not set them apart, but allowed them to be mingled together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:42
verses.text: Let our argument also about the Devil be the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:43
verses.text: For on this account He hath left him also to be here, in order that he might render thee the stronger, in order that he may make the athlete more illustrious, in order that the contests may be greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:44
verses.text: When therefore any one says, why has God left the Devil here? say these words to him, because he not only does no harm to the wary and the heedful, but even profits them, not owing to his own purpose (for that is wicked), but owing to their courage who have used that wickedness aright.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:45
verses.text: Since he even fixed upon Job not on this account that he might make him more illustrious, but in order that he might upset him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:46
verses.text: On this account he is wicked both because of such an opinion and such a purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:47
verses.text: But notwithstanding he did no harm to the righteous man, but he rather rejoiced in the conflict as we accordingly shewed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:48
verses.text: Both the Demon shewed his wickedness and the righteous man his courage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:49
verses.text: But he does upset many says one: owing to their weakness, not owing to his own strength: for this too has been already proved by many examples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:50
verses.text: Direct thine own intention aright then, and thou shalt never receive harm from any, but shall get the greatest gain, not only from the good but even from the wicked.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:51
verses.text: For on this account, as I have before said, God has suffered men to be with one another, and especially the wicked with the good, in order that they may bring them over to their own virtue.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:52
verses.text: Hear at least what Christ saith to his disciples, "The Kingdom of heaven is like unto a woman who took leaven and hid it in three measures of meal".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:53
verses.text: So that the righteous have the power of leaven, in order that they may transfer the wicked to their own manner of conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:54
verses.text: But the righteous are few, for the leaven is small.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:55
verses.text: But the smallness in no way injures the lump, but that little quantity converts the whole of the meal to itself by means of the power inherent in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:56
verses.text: So accordingly the power also of the righteous has its force not in the magnitude of their number, but in the grace of the Spirit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:57
verses.text: There were twelve Apostles.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:58
verses.text: Dost thou see how little is the leaven? The whole world was in unbelief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:59
verses.text: Dost thou see how great is the lump? But those twelve turned the whole world to themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:60
verses.text: The leaven and the lump had the same nature but not the same manner of conduct.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:61
verses.text: On this account he left the wicked in the midst of the good, that since they are of the same nature as the righteous they may also become of the same purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:62
verses.text: Remember these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:63
verses.text: With these stop the mouths of the indolent, the dissolute, the slothful, the indisposed towards the labours of virtue, those who accuse their common Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:64
verses.text: "Thou hast sinned" he saith "be still".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:65
verses.text: "Do not add a second more grievous sin".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:66
verses.text: It is not so grievous to sin, as after the sin to accuse the Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:67
verses.text: Take knowledge of the cause of the sin, and thou wilt find that it is none other than thyself who hast sinned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:68
verses.text: Everywhere there is a need of a good intention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:69
verses.text: I have shewn you this not from simple reasoning only, but from the case of fellow-servants living in the world itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:70
verses.text: Do thou also use this proof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:71
verses.text: Thus too our common master will judge us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:72
verses.text: Learn this method of proof, and no one will be able to reason with you.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:73
verses.text: Is any a fornicator? Shew him another who is self-restrained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:74
verses.text: Is any covetous and rapacious? Shew him one who gives alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:75
verses.text: Does he live in jealousy and envy? Shew him one clean from passion.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:76
verses.text: Is he overcome by anger? Bring into the midst one who is living in wisdom, for we must not only have recourse to ancient example, but take our models from present times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:77
verses.text: For even to-day by the grace of God, good deeds are done not less than of old.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:78
verses.text: Is a man incredulous? and does he think that the scriptures are false? Does he not believe that Job was such as he was? Shew him another man, emulating the life of that righteous person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:79
verses.text: Thus will the Master also judge us: He places fellow servants with fellow-servants, nor does he give sentence according to his own judgment, in order that no one may begin to say again, as that servant said, who was entrusted with the talent, and who instead of a talent brought the accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:80
verses.text: "Thou art an austere man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:81
verses.text: For he ought to mourn, because he did not double the talent, but rendered his sin the more grievous, by adding to his own idleness, his accusation against the Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:82
verses.text: For what saith he? "I knew thee that thou art an austere man".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:83
verses.text: O miserable, and wretched, ungrateful and lazy man! Thou oughtest to have accused thine own idleness, and to have taken away somewhat from thy former sin.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:84
verses.text: But thou in bringing an account against the master hast doubled thy sin instead of doubling thy talent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:85
verses.text: On this account God places together servants and servants in order that the one set may judge the other, and that some being judged by the others may not be able for the future to accuse the master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:86
verses.text: On this account, he saith "The Son of Man cometh in the glory of his Father".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:87
verses.text: See the equality of the glory: he does not say in glory like to the glory of the Father, but in the glory of the Father, and will gather together all the nations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:88
verses.text: Terrible is the tribunal: terrible to the sinful, and the accountable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:89
verses.text: Since to those who are conscious to themselves of good works, it is desirable and mild.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:90
verses.text: "And he will place the sheep on his right hand, and the kids on his left".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:91
verses.text: Both these and those are men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:92
verses.text: For what reason then are those indeed sheep but these kids? Not that thou mayest learn a difference in their nature, but the difference in their purpose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:93
verses.text: But for what reason are they who did not show compassion kids? Because that animal is unfruitful and is not able to contribute services, either by its milk, or by progeny, or by its hair, to those who possess it, being on all sides destitute of such a contribution as this, on account of the immaturity of its age.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:94
verses.text: On this account he has called those who bear no fruit, by comparison, kids, but those on the right hand sheep.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:95
verses.text: For from these the offering is great, both of their natural wool, their progeny, and their milk.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:96
verses.text: What then does he say to them? "Ye saw me hungering and ye fed me, naked and ye clothed me, a stranger and ye took me in".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:97
verses.text: Again to those he says the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:98
verses.text: And yet both these and those were alike men, both these and those received the same promises, the same rewards were assigned to both on doing right.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:99
verses.text: The same person came both to these and to those, with the same nakedness: and to these and to those with the same hunger, and in the same way and a stranger.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:100
verses.text: All things were alike to those and to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:101
verses.text: How then was the end not the same? Because the purpose did not permit it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:102
verses.text: For this alone made the difference.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:103
verses.text: On this account the one set went to Gehenna, but the other to the Kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:104
verses.text: But if the Devil were the cause to them of their sins, these would not be destined to be chastened, when another sinned and drove them on.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:105
verses.text: Dost thou see here both those who sin, and those who do good works? Dost thou see how on seeing their fellow-servants they were silenced? Come and let us bring our discourse to another example for thy benefit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:106
verses.text: There were ten virgins he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:107
verses.text: Here again there are purposes which are upright, and purposes which are sinful, in order thou mayest see side by side, both the sins of the one and the good works of the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:108
verses.text: For the comparison makes these things the plainer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:109
verses.text: And these and those were virgins; and these were five, and also those.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:110
verses.text: All awaited the bridegroom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:111
verses.text: How then did some enter in, and others did not enter in? Because some indeed were churlish, and others were gentle and loving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:112
verses.text: Dost thou see again that the purpose determined the nature of the end, not the Devil? Dost thou see that the judgments were parallel, and that the verdict given proceeds from those who are like each other? Fellow-servants will judge fellow-servants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:113
verses.text: Dost thou wish that I should shew thee a comparison arising from contrasts? for there is one also from contrasts so that the condemnation may become the greater.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:114
verses.text: "The men of Nineveh" he saith "shall rise up, and shall condemn this generation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:115
verses.text: The judged are no longer alike, for the one are barbarians, the others are Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:116
verses.text: The one enjoyed prophetic teaching, the others were never partakers of a divine instruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:117
verses.text: And this is not the only difference, but the fact that in that case a servant went to them, in this the master; and that man came and proclaimed an overthrow; but this man declared the glad tidings of a kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:118
verses.text: Which of these was it the more likely, would believe? The barbarians, and ignorant, and they who had never partaken of divine teaching, or they who had from their earliest age been trained in prophetic books? To every one, it is plain, that the Jews would be more likely to believe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:119
verses.text: But the contrary took place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:120
verses.text: And these disbelieved the Master when he preached a kingdom of heaven, but those believed their fellow-servant when he threatened an overthrow: in order that their goodness, and these men's folly might be manifested to a greater degree.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:121
verses.text: Is there a Demon? a Devil? chance? or Fate? has not each become the cause to himself both of evil, and of virtue? For if they themselves were not to be liable to account, he would not have said that they shall judge this generation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:122
verses.text: Nor would he have said that the Queen of the South would condemn the Jews.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:123
verses.text: For then indeed not only will one people condemn another people, but one man will often judge a whole people, when they who, it is allowed, might readily have been deceived, are found to remain undeceived, and they who ought in every way to have the advantage, turn out to be worsted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:124
verses.text: On this account, we made mention of Adam and of Job, for there is necessity to revert to that subject, so as to put the finish to our discourse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:125
verses.text: He attacked Adam indeed by means of mere words, but Job by means of deeds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:126
verses.text: For the one he denuded of all his wealth, and deprived of his children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:127
verses.text: But from this man he took not away anything, great or little of his possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:128
verses.text: But let us rather examine the very words and the method of the plot.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:129
verses.text: "The serpent came" saith he "and said to the woman, What is it that God hath said, ye shall not eat of every tree which is in the garden?" Here it is a serpent; there a woman, in the case of Job: mean while great is the difference between the counsellors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:130
verses.text: The one is a servant, the other a partner of the man's life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:131
verses.text: She is a helpmate, but the other is under subjection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:132
verses.text: Dost thou see how unpardonable this is? Eve indeed, the servant in subjection deceived: but him not even his partner, and helpmate could overthrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:133
verses.text: But let us see what he saith.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:134
verses.text: "What is this that God hath said, thou shalt not eat of every tree?" Assuredly indeed God did not say this but the opposite.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:135
verses.text: See the villany of the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:136
verses.text: He said that which was not spoken, in order that he might learn what was spoken.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:137
verses.text: What then did the woman? She ought to have silenced him, she ought not to have exchanged a word with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:138
verses.text: In foolishness she declared the judgment of the Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:139
verses.text: Thereby she afforded the Devil a powerful handle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:140
verses.text: See what an evil it is to commit ourselves rashly to our enemies, and to conspirators against us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:141
verses.text: On this account Christ used to say, "Give not holy things to the dogs, neither cast ye your pearls before the swine, lest they turn and rend you".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:142
verses.text: And this happened in the case of Eve.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:143
verses.text: She gave the holy things to the dog, to the swine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:144
verses.text: He trod under foot the words: and turned and rent the woman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:145
verses.text: And see how he works evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:146
verses.text: "Ye shall not die the death" saith he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:147
verses.text: Give me your attention on this point, that the woman was able to understand the deceit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:148
verses.text: For he immediately announced his enmity, and his warfare against God, he immediately contradicted Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:149
verses.text: Let it be so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:150
verses.text: Before this thou declaredst the judgment to one who wished to learn it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:151
verses.text: After this why didst thou follow one who said the opposite? God said "ye shall die the death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:152
verses.text: The Devil made answer to this and said "ye shall not die the death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:153
verses.text: What could be clearer than this warfare? From what other quarter ought one to learn the enemy and the foe, than from his answer returned to God? She ought then immediately to have fled from the bait, she ought to have started back from the snare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:154
verses.text: "Ye shall not die the death," saith he "for God knoweth, that on the day on which ye eat, your eyes shall be opened, and ye shall be as Gods.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:155
verses.text: In hope of a greater promise she cast away the goods in her hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:156
verses.text: He promised that he would make them Gods, and cast them down into the tyranny of death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:157
verses.text: Whence then O woman didst thou believe the Devil? What good didst thou discern? Was not the trustworthiness of the lawgiver sufficient to prove that the one was God, both creator and framer of the world, and the other the Devil and an enemy? And I do not say the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:158
verses.text: Thou thoughtest that he was a mere serpent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:159
verses.text: Ought a serpent to claim such equality that thou shouldest tell him the Master's judgment? Thou seest that it was possible to perceive the deceit, but she would not, and yet God gave many proofs of his own beneficence and shewed forth his care of his works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:160
verses.text: For he formed man, who had not existed before; and breathed a soul into him, and made him according to his image, making him ruler of all things upon the earth, and granted him a helpmate, planted Paradise, and having committed to him the use of the rest of the trees, refused him the taste of one only: and this very prohibition he made for man's advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:161
verses.text: But the Devil manifested no good things by his deed, whether little, or great: but exciting the woman with mere words and puffing her up with vain hopes, thus he deceived her.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:162
verses.text: But nevertheless she considered the Devil to be more worthy of credit than God, although God shewed forth his good will by his works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:163
verses.text: The woman believed in one who professed mere words, and nothing else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:164
verses.text: Dost thou see how, from folly alone and sloth, and not from force, the deceit happened? and in order that thou mayest learn it more clearly hear how the scripture accuses the woman: For it does not say, being deceived, but "seeing the tree that it was fair, she ate".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:165
verses.text: So that the blame belongs to her uncontrolled vision, not to the deceit alone which comes from the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:166
verses.text: For she was defeated by yielding to her own desire, not by the wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:167
verses.text: of the Demon.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:168
verses.text: On this account she did not have the benefit of pardon, but though she said, "the serpent deceived me," she paid the uttermost penalty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:169
verses.text: For it was in her power not to have fallen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:170
verses.text: And in order that thou mayest understand this more clearly, come, let us conduct our discourse to the case of Job; from the defeated to the vanquisher, from the conquered to the conqueror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:171
verses.text: For this man will give us greater zeal, so that we may raise our hands against the Devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:172
verses.text: There he who deceived and conquered was a serpent; here the tempter was a woman, and she did not prevail: and yet at least she was far more persuasive than he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:173
verses.text: For to Job after the destruction of his wealth, after the loss of his children, after being stripped bare of all his goods, her wiles were added.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:174
verses.text: But in the other case there was nothing of this kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:175
verses.text: Adam did not suffer the destruction of his children, nor did he lose his wealth: he did not sit upon a dunghill, but inhabited a Paradise of luxury and enjoyed all manner of fruits, and fountains and rivers, and every other kind of security.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:176
verses.text: Nowhere was there labour or pain, or despair and cares, or reproaches, and insults, or the countless ills which assailed Job: but nevertheless, when nothing of this kind existed, he fell and was overthrown.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:177
verses.text: Is it not evident that it was on account of sloth? Even so therefore as the other, when all these things beset him, and weighed upon him, stood nobly and did not fall, is it not evident that his steadfastness was owing to his vigilance of soul?.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:178
verses.text: On both sides, beloved, reap the utmost gain, and avoid the imitation of Adam knowing how many ills are begotten of indolence: and imitate the piety of Job, learning how many glorious things spring from earnestness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:179
verses.text: Consider him, the conqueror throughout, and thou shalt have much consolation in all pain and peril.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:180
verses.text: For as it were in the common theatre of the world that blessed and noble man stands forth, and by means of the sufferings which happened to him discourses to all to bear all things which befal them nobly, and never give in to the troubles which come upon them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:181
verses.text: For verily, there is no human suffering which cannot receive consolation from thence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:182
verses.text: For the sufferings which are scattered over the whole world, these came together, and bore down upon one body, even his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:183
verses.text: What pardon then shall there be for him who is unable to bear with thankfulness his share of the troubles which are brought upon him? Since he appears not bearing a part only, but the entire ills of all men, and in order that thou mayest not condemn the extravagance of my words, come, and let us take in hand severally the ills that came upon him, and bring forward this fulfilment of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:184
verses.text: And if thou wishest, let us first bring forward that which seems to be the most unendurable of all, I mean poverty, and the pain which arises from it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:185
verses.text: For everywhere all men bewail this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:186
verses.text: What was poorer then than Job, who was poorer than the outcasts at the baths, and those who sleep in the ashes of the furnace, poorer in fact than all men? For these indeed have one ragged garment, but he sat naked, and had only the garment which nature supplies, the clothing of the flesh, and this the Devil destroyed on all sides, with a distressing kind of decay.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:187
verses.text: Again these poor folk are at least under the roof of the porches at the baths, and are covered with a shelter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:188
verses.text: But he continued always to pass his nights in the open air, not having even the consolation of a bare roof.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:189
verses.text: And, what is still greater, the fact that these are conscious of many terrible evils within themselves, but he was conscious of nothing against himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:190
verses.text: For this is to be noticed in each of the things which happened to him, a thing which caused him greater pain, and produced more perplexity; the ignorance of the reason of what took place.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:191
verses.text: These persons then, as I said, would have many things with which to reproach themselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:192
verses.text: And this contributes no little to consolation in calamity; to be conscious in oneself of being punished justly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:193
verses.text: But he was deprived of this consolation, and while exhibiting a conversation full of virtue, endured the fate of those who had dared to do extreme wickedness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:194
verses.text: And these folk who are with us, are poor from the outset, and from the beginning are versed in calamity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:195
verses.text: But he endured calamity in which he was unversed, experiencing the immense change from wealth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:196
verses.text: As then the knowledge of the cause of what takes place, is the greatest consolation; so it is not less than this, to have been versed in poverty from the beginning, and so to continue in it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:197
verses.text: Of both these consolations that man was deprived, and not even then, did he fall away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:198
verses.text: Dost thou see him indeed come to extreme poverty, even in comparison with which it is impossible to find a fellow? For what could be poorer than the naked who has not even a roof over him? Yea rather not even was it in his power to enjoy the bare ground, but he sat upon the dunghill.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:199
verses.text: Therefore whenever thou seest thyself come to poverty, consider the suffering of the just one, and straightway thou shalt rise up, and shake off every thought of despondency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:200
verses.text: This one calamity therefore seems to men to be the groundwork of all sufferings together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:201
verses.text: And the second after it, yea rather before it, is the affliction of the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:202
verses.text: Who then was even so disabled? Who endured such disease? Who received or saw any one else receive so great an affliction? No one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:203
verses.text: Little by little his body was wasted, and a stream of worms on every side issued from his limbs, the running was constant, and the evil smell which surrounded him was strong, and the body being destroyed little by little, and decaying with such putrefaction, used to make food distasteful and hunger was to him strange and unusual.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:204
verses.text: For not even was he able to enjoy the nourishment which was given to him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:205
verses.text: For saith he "I see my food to be loathsome".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:206
verses.text: Whenever then thou fallest into weakness, O man, remember that body and that saintly flesh.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:207
verses.text: For it was saintly and pure, even when it had so many wounds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:208
verses.text: And if any one belong to the army, and then unjustly and without any reasonable pretext, be hanged upon the pillory, and has his sides rasped to pieces, let him not think the matter to be a reproach, nor let him give way to the pain when he thinks upon this saint.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:209
verses.text: But this man, says one, has much comfort and consolation in knowing that God was bringing these sufferings upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:210
verses.text: This indeed especially troubled and disturbed him, to think that the just God who had in every way been served by him, was at war with him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:211
verses.text: And he was not able to find any reasonable pretext for what took place, since, when at least he afterwards learned the cause, see what piety he shewed, for when God said to him "Dost thou think that I have had dealings with thee in order that thou mightest appear righteous?" conscious-stricken he says "I will lay my hand upon my mouth, once have I spoken but to a second word I will not proceed," and again "as far as the hearing of the ear I have heard thee before, but now mine eye hath seen thee, wherefore I have held myself to be vile, and am wasted away, and I consider myself to be earth and ashes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:212
verses.text: But if thou thinkest that this is sufficient for consolation, thou wilt thyself also be able to experience this comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:213
verses.text: And even if thou dost not suffer any of these misfortunes at the hands of God but owing to the insolence of men; and yet givest thanks and dost not blaspheme him who is able to prevent them indeed, but who permits them for the sake of testing thee: just as they who suffer at the hands of God are crowned, so also thou shalt obtain the same reward, because thou hast borne nobly the calamities which were brought upon thee from men, and didst give thanks to him who was able indeed to hinder them, but not willing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:214
verses.text: Behold then! thou hast seen poverty and disease, and both in the extremest degree brought upon this just man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:215
verses.text: Dost thou wish that I should shew thee the warfare at nature's hands, in such excessive degree waged then against this noble man? He lost ten children, the ten at one fell swoop, the ten in the very bloom of youth, ten who displayed much virtue, and that not by the common law of nature, but by a violent and pitiable death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:216
verses.text: Who could be able to recount so great a calamity? No one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:217
verses.text: Whenever therefore thou losest son and daughter together, have recourse to this just man, and thou shalt find altogether much comfort for thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:218
verses.text: Were these then the only misfortunes which happened to him? The desertion and treachery of his friends, and the gibes, and raillery, and the mockery and derision, and the tearing in pieces by all, was something intolerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:219
verses.text: For the character of calamities is not of such a kind, that they who reproach us about our calamities are wont to vex our soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:220
verses.text: Not only was there no one to soothe him but many even on many sides beset him with taunts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:221
verses.text: And thou seest him lamenting this bitterly, and saying "but even you too fell upon me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:222
verses.text: And he calls them pitiless, and says "My neighbours have rejected me, and my servants spake against me, and I called the sons of my concubines, and they turned away from me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:223
verses.text: "And others" saith he "sport upon me, and I became the common talk of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:224
verses.text: And my very raiment" saith he "abhorred me".

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:225
verses.text: These things at least are unbearable to hear, still more to endure in their reality, extreme poverty, and intolerable disease new and strange, the loss of children so many and so good, and in such a manner, reproaches and gibes, and insults from men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:226
verses.text: Some indeed mocked and some reproached and others despised; not only enemies, but even friends; not only friends, but even servants, and they not only mock and reproach, but even abhorred him, and this not for two or three, or ten days, but for many months; and (a circumstance which happened in that man's case alone) not even had he comfort by night, but the delusions of terrors by night were a greater aggravation of his misfortunes by day.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:227
verses.text: For that he endured more grievous things in his sleep, hear what he says "why dost thou frighten me in sleep, and terrify me in visions?" What man of iron, what heart of steel could have endured so many misfortunes? For if each of these was unbearable in itself, consider what a tumult their simultaneous approach excited.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:228
verses.text: But nevertheless he bore all these, and in all that happened to him he sinned not, nor was there guile in his lips.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:229
verses.text: Let the sufferings of that man then be the medicines for our ills, and his grievous surging sea the harbour of our sufferings, and in each of the accidents which befal us, let us consider this saint, and seeing one person exhausting the misfortunes of the universe, we shall conduct ourselves bravely in those which fall to our share, and as to some affectionate mother, stretching forth her hands on all sides, and receiving and reviving her terrified children, so let us always flee to this book, and even if the pitiable troubles of all men assail us, let us take sufficient comfort for all and so depart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:230
verses.text: And if thou sayest, he was Job, and for this reason bore all this, but I am not like him; thou suppliest me with a greater accusation against thyself and fresh praise of him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:231
verses.text: For it is more likely that thou shouldest be able to bear all this than he.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:232
verses.text: Why pray? Because he indeed was before the day of grace and of the law, when there was not much strictness of life, when the grace of the Spirit was not so great, when sin was hard to fight against, when the curse prevailed and when death was terrible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:233
verses.text: But now our wrestlings have become easier, all these things being removed after the coming of Christ; so that we have no excuse, when we are unable to reach the same standard as he, after so long a time, and such advantage, and so many gifts given to us by God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: Homilies Concerning The Power of Demons III 1:234
verses.text: Considering therefore all these things, that misfortunes were greater for him, and that when the conflict was more grievous, then he stripped for the contest; let us bear all that comes upon us nobly, and with much thankfulness, in order that we may be able to obtain the same crown as he, by the grace and lovingkindness of Jesus Christ our Lord, with whom be glory to the Father together with the Holy Spirit, now and always and for ever and ever, Amen.
